completed my review here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1f7LW0wFt70VJCXSLqitKxuwPVLsZNqMuMXnAspUNDM4/edit?usp=sharing

Well. First of all: this ONE is a disappointment. And word ONE is marked for ONE special reason. A-1. That explains everything because of ONE simple rule: If you see A-1 as a studio, but the name of the show is not Shinsekai Yori -- That show is approximately 101% screwed.
Before I shall start my review, there is two details to go: 1)Yes. I am big fan of Fate series. 2)I've checked out manga before watching.
And now things get started.
1.Story
If you read the manga then you might already knew about specific storyline In Fate/apocrypha. If not -- lemme explain that briefly: a little bit fast&chaotic.And word fast is not as fast as We can see in show itself. I mean there is a lot of moments in storyline that was cut-off and a lot of additional material were added to a mix with ~3-times speed-up. The main idea evaporates because action is so intense and unstoppable that you can't sense usual Fate atmosphere. All you see is bunch of random sketches with a bunch of plot holes which gives you a signal like Giant Flashy Colourful Sign "THERE IS SOMETHING MISSING, M8. TRY TO FIGURE IT OUT BY YOURSELF".


tl;dr:A Lot Of Plot Holes.


2.Art

Art and drawing isn't the main problem. It's just mediocre. The real problem are bad animation. I mean some problems with guy who get all the budget, but don't want to pay a proper price for a proper work. And by word proper I mean Good or better. But no-no-no! Money well spent and viewers will eat anything, cuz look: we've got Fate in our title. To be more concrete about the problem -- animations are cheap but with old methods of reaching not bad effect for lower price. A lots LOTS of frames are drawn horribly and some camera angle rotations can cause not motion sickness but discomfort for sure. Also the colour palette is dark(sometimes Unnecessarily dark). For sure that is a plus for an atmosphere of growing tension(Just like in Fate/Zero). But there is one more thing, that ruins this atmosphere...


tl;dr:Cheap mediocre animations.


3.Sound

...Two words: FACE PALM. Just try to watch first 3 episodes and pay attention to Action and Musical Theme on background. You will get what I'm saying. Some themes are Just. Doesn't. Fit The Damn Place! And "some" is not equal to "few". But equal to "Frequently". Opening are not that bad but not good neither. Ending was insta-skipped right after one try of watching. And that is not because of sound only. (Sorry for wrong place) But because of content inside. Opening itself is ~70% of meaningless fight scenes. Literally MeaningLess. Sound design of battles are awful. Sounds that weapons are making are giving me reason to turn down the volume(Don't try. Horror inside.). But still there is bright side:CVs did some nice work for characters. But wait. Isn't the characters next?


tl;dr:Messy Sound Design.


4.Characters

And now there is time to say that!

*Inhales*

The manga was better at it.(Yet still not that good)

No, guys there is no joke there. In show there was literally almost no character development. But what do you want from 25 episodes for Over(!) 25 characters?

Just not enough time for all of them. No reasons were revealed(Almost none of them. Remember how character's reasons were shown in any Fate show except Ilya-series. Feel the difference now?) Main idea spins just around Mordred, Astolfo, Jeanne, Fran., Siegfried&sieg. And? Where is Other servants? NOT ENOUGH TIME AND SPACE FOR THEM. Not Enough. We still got some characters to understand but no. Manga showed a little bit more but still not enough. Yet still it has its bright side. There is some wise thoughts and words inside. Not many, but we have them. I personally watching anything in search of food for my mind. And I found some down there. Even if obvious, but still: This part of Fate series had smallest impact.

Because there is no time to actually get interested in some character due to bad development. Sadly.


tl;dr:Fail In Char.Dev.


Summary Time:

I should say some obvious things there. Fate Apocrypha had a potential due to interesting Idea. Idea which doubles scale of already great Franchise and even have chance to get it up to whole new level. But to perform That serious actions Anybody will strongly need 2 precious resources: Time and Mind.

 A lot of them. 

 In 25 episodes there is no chance that idea of This Giant Scale will be fully developed and shown from all important angles.

 Manga is not that great but still feels better even if there are some details from show are missing.

 And of course: There is a Colossal potential in this one. Was. Before this disappointing performance.


tl;dr:Great Potential. But crappy realization.

Fate shows live and die by their characters.  Past series (Fate/Zero) have impressed by delving deep into the motivations of the large (14+ characters) cast, each with a well explored personality and strategy, and then setting them lose upon each other.  
Fate/Apocrypha ups the ante by doubling the roster to 14v14 and promising back-to back battle royales.  The heroes are stronger too, many of them being divine and/or near-immortal.  I believe these promises are the root of this show's failure.
Since there simply isn't enough time to explore all 29+ of these heroes in 2 wars, the show rushes and glosses overand uses caricatures and stale/cliche themes.  More than 1/3 of the way through the series, and the only character we've seen really explored is Seig, a cliche artificial life form who seeks to free others of his kind, and who isn't even a participant in the grail war!


Power creep is an important problem in Fate/Apocrypha, as it significantly lowers the stakes.  Why should I care if characters we are told are divine or essentially invincible do battle, especially if I have no idea what anyone other than the golemancer and Vlad are planning?  In Fate/Zero, if a character lost, their dream died with them so we cared much more - here, they are but one of 14 on their side, so the others could probably take up the slack and nothing really is achieved.


All in all I don't recommend this show.  I will continue watching because watching this show make mistakes helps me to understand better what made my favourite anime so enjoyable.


TL;DR - too many characters, none of whom are fleshed out enough to capture interest.  Too much power creep (divine, near-immortal characters, and 14v14 instead of 7-hero FFA) to make battles feel impactful or important.  Too much screentime given to development of minor character's cliche side story (Seig).  Skip this one.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS
This is far from being one of the most popular show of the Fate series, but I liked Fate/Apocrypha quite a bit, and actually enjoyed it a lot more than Fate/stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works (for which I don't particularly care). While being as dark in its setting as the other main Fate titles, Fate/Apocrypha tend to be more optimistic than those other shows. Fate/Apocrypha is also different from the other shows in that it is a war between two groups of seven master/servant duos, in contrast with the usual battle royale setting.
The story:
There may apparently be two sides in this battle,but as one would expect from a Fate title, it is actually quite a bit more complicated than that, and treason is always near. One of the advantages of servants fighting in groups is the balancing (or lack of) that it can entail in fights. It is possible to have servants on one side outnumbering the others; even though this would often occur in previous Fate shows, it has never been as common as in this one. This allows for truly broken servants to be defeated nonetheless.


Appart from that, the story is nothing special. The main goals of the characters evolve as the balance of power shifts, but nothing that hasn't been seen before.



The secondary characters:


Let's be honest, a huge part of the reason why Fate is so popular is because of the excitement that seeing legendary heroes summoned for the sole purpose of fighting entails. And here we have twice the usual number of servants! Of course, that also means that we spend less time on each master/servant duo, as there are more, but the focus of this anime is different from that of the previous shows. Here, we don't see the masters that much, at most we know about their motivations and personality; there is however a lot more time dedicated to seeing the servants. Not all of them are well developed, but they have a lot more interaction among each other than in the previous Fate shows.


There are two servant/master duos which are a bit of an exception here, one of them having saber of red as a servant. I personally enjoyed these two characters a lot, as they were more in sync than maybe any other servant/master duo in the whole Fate series. They were not developed a lot, but each of their appearances were really great to see.



The main characters:


Now, here is the worst part of this anime: the "main" characters. Not all of them are equally badly written, but they are certainly not great. Let's start with the worst of them all: Amakusa Shirou. I consider him as a main character as he is the main antagonist of the show. The principal issue with Shirou is that he is fucking random. We don't know what made him that way, except for a few unclear memories, and his powers are never explained either (no strong link with his identity I believe). He may already have appeared in another Type-Moon story where he got more background, I actually don't know, but that doesn't change the fact that this character doesn't make any sense in the scope of this show.


The second worst character is Jeanne D'Arc. Really, why is she here? Well, one of here main purpose is to introduce the fact that ruler-class servants exists, in order to legitimate Shirou's backstory. This doesn't change the fact that she is a huge joke of a ruler-class servant (neutral my ass, even Astolfo makes fun of her for being completely partial). She actually has some cool moments where her purity of heart isn't tainted by her realistic view of the world (one of the main focus of the show in regards to her personality), but I truly hated the romance that the show tried to force in her relationship with Sieg (I'll talk about him in a second). It really didn't make much sense and it was neither necessary nor well-developed. Furthermore, it led to a horribly cheesy and illogical scene at the end of the show.


Last but not least, Sieg. I actually don't hate Sieg as much as others do, but what I agree on with most of the criticism that he suffered from was how useless he was in the show. It would have been way better to keep Siegfried as a character, while having more time for developing other characters. Now, I don't think that Sieg is that cliché of a character. Why does he suddenly become so altruistic? Well, my personal theory is that Sieg's personality was in a huge part written by copying Siegfried's. This is especially visible as he suddenly wants to help people after receiving Siegfried's heart and seeing Siegfried in his imagination. He makes the pledge to help people at this precise moment. This is quite the ironic situation as this would both mean that Siegfried was not able to give true freedom to Sieg, and that Sieg's heroism throughout the whole anime is not even his own.



The music and the animation:


The music in the openings and endings is quite good good imo, especially "Désir" by GARNiDELiA. Otherwise, I didn't really care for the music in the show itself.


The animation is good, as are the graphics, as one could expect from A-1 Pictures. I however have to mention the strange shift in animation during certain fight scenes toward the end of the show. During some of the most spectacular battles, the animation would stay as fluid as usual, while the graphics would become really simple, and the action would take place in a theoretical realm rather than in the reality of the surrounding of the characters (what I mean here is that nothing really made sense anymore). It is especially surprising as this occurs in several scenes rather than just one. I really don't know if this was an artistic choice or a lack of time (I would lean toward the latter), but it felt really strange though it did not really hinder my enjoyment of these fights.



Final thoughts:


I wrote quite a bit on the negative aspects of the show, but this was overall a really enjoyable watch, and it was all I asked from this anime. This anime is of course mostly interesting because of the servants, their stories, and developments. There is no strong main character here, neither is there a story that will blow your mind. But honestly, that is seldom the case in the Fate series.

Is this a good Anime?  TLDR Honest answer: Not really.
Contains Few Spoilers
Fate/Apocrypha suffers from a fundamental issue that most of the Fate Animes have which is, run time.  There's not enough time to develop 20+ unique characters in a 25 episode anime.  It's just physically impossible to give meaningful screen time to that many characters and have them in anyway shape or form fleshed out to an acceptable degree.  Anyone who has attempted to write stories would know.
That said, I personally think that the anime did an alright job with what it was likely given for a script.  Plot waspushed at a somewhat acceptable pace but certain events still did not feel like they had proper buildup or felt improperly transitioned into.


Certain aspects of the story are somewhat nonsensical and feel forced.  Seig's character is the perfect example of having a cool idea but not actually taking the time to connect all the points as to how the character finds himself flowing into the story.  He is absolutely thrusted into the story and given more screen time than he really deserves.  Why?  Because he is the Shirou Emiya of this story unfortunately.  He's a Mary Sue most likely due to being a "blank slate" type of character.  That said, I don't understand why they chose to develop another Shirou Emiya style character when they have a perfect example of a character who just works for this style of Fate Anime: Kiritsugu.  Doesn't require much effort to introduce as his skills and actions do the introductions for him.


Certain parts also lack proper screen continuity.  The side that is attempting to infiltrate the flying fortress is using airplanes to get close.  Jeanne gets blasted and wrestled to the ground off an airplane then magically teleports onto the fortress minutes later (Why even bother with the airplanes if you can get onto the fortress no problem?).


Animation is absolutely eye candy at certain parts.  Character designs are sleek and fit (most) of the cast.  Overall is very consistent but coloring becomes off in certain action scenes in the last stretch (Likely ran out of time, money, or both).


What this anime did achieve was:

1. Make me appreciate the Karna I pulled in Fate Grand Order over a year ago that I have sitting in my character bank at level 60.  

2. Make me an Astolfo fanboy.

3. Wish that they just figured out a way to make a 50 to 100 Episode anime for a Fate story that was affordable and paced well enough to make me enjoy and care about the cast that's present.  The story suffers so much from the 25 episode screen time constraint.

How do I put this. Fate/Apocrypha received a mixed amount of critics and praise to the point that I don’t even know if this is considered a successful anime or failure in the fate franchise. 
Putting my bias for the fate franchise, I’ll have to say the story for Apocrypha was really lack lustre. It felt as though there was no specific direction for the story. The twists and “shocks” didn’t really hit me hard or have any effect on me because I really can’t get behind the story.
Characters were all pretty good, Siegfried, Karna and Mordred in particular were really interesting. However, back ontothe story, making Sieg the main character was a disappointment as I felt the anime should have centred around Shirou, Sieg or Mordred instead of Sieg. Jeanne was an interesting addition to the character list. However with the giant roster of heroic spirits, you can’t help but feel certain characters didn’t receive too much of an introduction. Overall characters are still great and made me want to know them more.


Music used in the anime for its OP and ED were simply fantastic. Egoist has done it again, giving such a beautiful OP accompanied by Lisa’s Ash, these two OPs were really well done in my opinion and really shows an epic vibe between two opposing forces clashing. Desire ED was also a really heart warming ending that makes you feel for the character of Jeanne and the others.


How can one not talk about the animation used in fight scenes of fate though. Though not animated by Ufotable which made FSN famous for being called Unlimited Budget works. The animation was still really impressive, with breath taking action scenes in Karna and Sieg’s fights. 


All in all, I did enjoy the anime for its characters and fights scenes but not the story. Some will hate it and some will love it.

Short and to the sweet, I'm willing to bet there are fanfics out there which give a better treatment to the FATE universe than this series did.  Apocrypha takes the FATE cannon, throws it away, tries to cram every "Wouldn't it be cool if!?" idea into it and in the end only ends up destroying the characters and cannon of the series that came before it.
Are some of the new characters good?  Yes.  Could they have been done a lot better in a story up to the standard of UBW and Zero?  Absolutely. Fails the audience, fails the characters, fails the series.

I contemplated on how best to summarize this review for what seems like an exceedingly long time. It falls somewhere between the "Fate of anticlimactic ends", "Deus ex machina all day everyday" and the "Fate with the writer who dropped out of a literature degree after learning one literary mechanism - the anti-climax". It's Fate/Stay Night's less popular mass market cousin (twice removed). 
I mean rarely have I seen an anime with untapped potential with so many characters, so gratuitously running them all off a cliff. Fate/Apocrypha should NOT be a fan's introduction to the Fate series. Fate/Stay Night was not the best anime evercreated neither then nor now, but it made you care for the small crop of core characters, filled you with a sense of dread when they faced danger and when it dropped the big plot bombs it made you scream with glee and a certain sense of "dear god, they didn't just suggest that did they..." And when the characters died, it was without a shadow of a doubt, important and it made us care. Not Fate/Apocrypha. No.


Fate/Apocrypha is a mess of (and I repeat) questionable plot points (I cannot truly call them holes, since I myself could have misunderstood them), anti-climatic endings to characters - backgrounds for which sometime show flashes of brilliance but never explore anything beyond some rushed development or a few initial scenes, needless fan-service and ofcourse the deus ex machina,


Let's quickly go over my favorite ones:


*Spoiler Warning!*


1) The Ruler character is the only one richly developed along the lines of Saber or Shirou from Fate/Stay Night. However, she also falls victim to the anti-climax of just fighting and eventually dying. I mean everyone just seems to have a fight (and if the writer felt like it on that day, reflect a little bit) and just die. No real importance to any death, it just... happens. Case in point, Vlad Tepes, uses his Noble Phantasm (which has a pretty great motivation about why he wouldn't willingly use it, and just, dies after 10 mins of him being untouchable and is discarded like an after thought). It's nearly the same with everyone else.


2) Poorly developed backgrounds for the heroes galore. Siegfried, few lines about him and he dies. Mordred (he's FSN Saber's (woman's) daughter with another woman - I mean I understand poetic authority but really, come one) and wants...something. To be king or to ease his/her father/mother's burden - why the change of heart? What brought this on? Karna, what is his motivation? What does he want? Shakespeare. What exactly is his power with his writing. Why is he writing if he cannot make events come true? Why is Shirou afraid of him writing a tragedy? If he could've materialized his writing he could have influenced nearly everything in the story? So why the writing? WHY does Sieg have command spells?


3) And let's come to the anti-climaxes. Frakenstein's monster dies trying to kill Mordred a few scenes after she's humanized a bit. Mordred goes into a big fight and simply dies at the end. Siegfried, the original one, all of a sudden, simply dies trying to save Sieg. Vlad Tepes just dies a few scenes after he became a near unstoppable monster. Aviceborn is simply shot - although he does state that he simply wanted to create the golem and nothing more, but still the all important golem dies a few scenes later. It's just filled with gems like this.


4) The people who don't die and Deus-Ex machina. Sieg is special. But WHY? He has command spells, Great. He saves Astolfo who is self admittedly a weak character. He fights and kills Karna (seemingly a very powerful character) on the second attempt after being wiped on the first attempt. What did he simply try harder the second time? He loses Siegfried's power and immediately gains Frankenstein's Monster's power because he was hit by her Noble Phantasm - Great but why does this happen? And apparently someone who killed Vlad Tepes in his Phantasm form as well as fought Frankenstein's Monster originally now is killed by Sieg wielding the same power? Great. Okay so Blaster Tree killed her when she used it but Sieg survives when he uses it. Why? Ugh.. I just couldn't keep suspending my disbelief after a point.


5) The catering to otakus. Jack the Rippers backstory is refreshingly sensible however why is her character a loli? It kills the whole seriousness of the character and is unnecessary. Why is Astolfo suddenly a pink haired shota? Who is sexually abused by a dominatrix/tsundere master who seems to have been miscast from a Hentai? 


I'm sure there are other issues that I'm forgetting but overall Fate/Apocrypha seems to be a mass market anime masquerading as something greater than it is - a lot of potential which unfortunately never goes anywhere. It seems like an example of a studio rushing an anime out and try to be mass market by appealing to a larger fanbase by going all Charles Dickens with the number and variety of characters and the breadth of the story - thing is Charles Dickens wrote better and wove a better story. Hell maybe they could've outsourced the story to Shakespeare - I mean he WAS in the anime and did keep writing all the time - which was again, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing - just like the anime.

My review as a person who watched alot the Fate series (movies and ovas included) and was really exited to watch more.

As sound goes not greatnot bad, Egoist is definitely the highlight. not much too say here not a big point for me but raises the overrall of this review as it may be the high point in and otherwise lackluster anime.: 6 Competent


Well we get to the worst of what comes with this entry on the franchise the caracthers or the lack of development or knowledge of them. A good part of this anime was forgettable, the story was okay, but well executed. I mainly just watched it because Alstolfo. Bumps this up from a 4 to an 8. (This is the first show I've seen in Fate series, so I won't compare it to previous versions, and just judge this show based on someone with no previous knowledge of the series.)
Story: 6/10
The story had a premise that allowed me to continue watching Fate Apocrypha to the end, eventually as the story progressed it became more confusing on what they were truly getting towards. From what I've seen it's pretty much a basic Shounen anime; that simply adds historical and mythological characters; rather than being completely new. Pacing was well; however, the ending was getting way too rushed, so it was fairly mediocre.
Art: 7/10
Theart is relatively good, especially with character designs and effects. Though the art is not really memorable, and it's relatively normal for the basic anime looks. A lot of the fight animation looked very bad and choppy, and at times the art is inconsistent between different episodes. The backgrounds were unique, and really showed a unique perspective.


Sound 6/10


The music wasn't remarkable like previous A-1 pictures shows, but was pretty good. Watched the show in English dub, and it feels like some characters could have had different voices. It was not particularly memorable, but still decent enough not to bore me.


Character: 8/10


All of the main characters are dynamic and really have their own side to things. Even though many of these characters are historical and mythological; they make dynamic changes in their personality, that it takes more than just reading a wikipedia page about these people; and many unexpected things really happened with characters from their realistic counterparts in history and mythology. I feel like the cast is relatively memorable. The reason I can't give this a 9 or a 10 is because; they don't really show the backstories of the characters very well, and just show vague flashbacks.


Enjoyment: 9/10


I enjoyed the show as someone who's never seen the Fate series, the reason for that is because I'm a fan of this historical-mythological alternate mash-up fan-fiction of the creators, (the entire show was basically a fan-fiction, of these characters). But I would not likely rewatch the show, because it's not particularly strong in aspects relating to really making the story believable. Don't watch the show expecting it to be believable, and you may be enjoyed.


Overall: 7/10

In this anime everything is well thought and has a serious background, starting from it's name: Fate/Apocrypha. Apocrypha means a non-canonical work in a set of well established series, with regards to the Bible this means heresy. And this is what exactly Fate/Apocrypha is compared to the original Fate/Stay Night series: it is a heresy. That's why many Fate fans dislike it — most things are non-canonical here: rules of the Holy Grail War, involved parties and even place where events are unfolding.
As every part of the Fate series Apocrypha contains epic battles between heroes from different eras. But it has more than that toit, it is so much more than just battles. There are no truly good ore truly evil characters here: holy heroes commit terrible crimes and dark ones make great deeds. By the end of the day everything is about desires and the ways they are accomplished.


The plot has very loose and circumstantial connection to the original Fate series and may be seen as events unfolding in a parallel universe, though there are some hints that it may be a prequel to Fate/Zero series. It will be up to you to find them. Time is looped in these series and full understanding of some elements come only after second watching.


So if you prefer original Fate setting, stay away from this anime! But if your mind is open, if you are ready for unexpected, Fate/Apocrypha is for you. By the way it impacts watcher, by the level of emotions in arises it is one of the best in the Fate universe, I can compare it only to the original Stay Night work.


And last but not the least: the series features absolutely amazing music theme which involves deeply in the plot.

And now i'm in Fandom Hell
To start i've only watched Fate/zero and my opinion on is a little sour. I see the Fate/series concept super interesting but i feel that they didn't fully capitalize on it but never the less i wanted to give Apocrypha a go
Now as i just mentioned typemoon hasn't managed to make a interesting enough story in the fate series yet and in this one i feel its quite the same with the overall story i never really wanted either side to win since they didn't give me enough reason to root for either of them but on the flip sidei did find myself enjoying the characters especially the servant characters as each them show more emotions that a large amount of the human characters\n\n
The one thing is always consistent with the fate series is the action and this anime doesn't disappoint in fact it improves it tenfold as each battle between the servants fells powerful and with every hit you feel it thanks to the sound design.\n\n
Overall i feel like the fate series has nailed its overall feel but it still fails to make any of its human protagonists likable if they can do that and keep it similar to apocrypha i think they will have finally made a perfect Fate anime

***SPOILER FREE***
After the sublime experience that was Fate/Zero and the entertainment extravaganza that was Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works, I went into Fate/Apocrypha with high-expectations and also to quench my thirst for a Fate story by the time Heaven's Feel would be released. Sadly, while Apocrypha began on an enjoyable and intriguing note, the story really lost steam after the first 10-12 episodes or so. 
While I appreciate the underlying theme of the story (a person getting his/her desired wish), it is the execution that I have a problem with. The selection of historical/mythological personalities who act as servants are varied and entertaining, however, theirpowers and abilities are a bit incongruous especially the Assassin of Red who's talents and abilities lean more towards that of a Caster. 


As the series drags on you are gripped by a sensation of fatigue and annoyance and yet you have invested too much time into the series to leave it half-way. I frequently found myself skipping through scenes upon scenes of predictable emotional turmoil and existential crisis just so that I could advance through the main-story. There are a few things however that keep things interesting, namely the Lancers of both factions along with the Caster of the Red faction who deserved a bit more screen-time in my opinion. Other than that, some Servants were reduced to being comedy-reliefs with little else to do than make cute faces and provide awkward moments for the lead characters. 


The Soundtrack deserves mention because the title-track was especially fitting for the epic-scale battle sequences as well as the one-one fights. The Art and Animation too was a treat to watch but not throughout the series. In some episodes the art was a bit too stiff and 'Trigger' like for my taste. 


All in all, it was an experience that was as my rating suggests 'Fair'. It could easily have turned bad were it not for the characterizations of a few of the servants and some genuine moments of emotional depth displayed by the masters.

Honestly, I feel like the war was actually very one sided. Everything was way to convenient for the Black Faction. From Sieg being saved so many times for no real reason, just for the plot's sake, to Red Faction servants going against eachother while forgetting their role in the war: obtaining the Great Holy Grail. I truly hated that the story completely went on Black Faction's side when Red Faction could've easily won had Sieg not have such a godly luck. Like, even the Ruler, the supposedly impartial servant fell in love with him pretty much at first sight and made so exceptions for himand Black Faction just because she felt like it. I hated how the plot had so many holes and didn't make much sense just to make Sieg win and happy ending as always. I'm going to be honest, I actually wanted to see something different for once, for Fate Apocrypha to not turn out to be the typical shounen anime. The difference between it and the other shounen animes is that Sieg didn't even train or do anything at all to get his power or to accomplish many things. Pretty much everything was handed to him miraculously, it was honestly very annoying. I was hoping Red Faction would win and make Shirou's wish true in that anime world, it would've been a good and realistic ending for me. But I still voted with a 9 on this anime because other than Sieg and Black Faction's unfair luck, I loved the battles, the feelings the characters had, I loved the Red Faction Servants, I feel like their personalities were more unique than the others' and Shirou as well, he stayed true to his wish and attained the Great Holy Grail through his own efforts, even though the ''impartial'' Ruler didn't like it and decided to stop him. I also loved Red Saber and her master, Achilles and Atalanta too, Red Faction made this anime really enjoyable to me. It would've been a clean 10 if they had won.

I'm going to keep this short.
I gave the anime a 4 overall. It was enjoyable at times, but for some stretches outright stupidly boring or annoying.
Art itself was good, but the visual representation was a mess of particle effects in most fights. That really made some of the most important scenes completely negligible. Almost as if they had to buy time because the story wouldn't be enough. 
In the end it was just who has the bigger light beam illuminating the sky, truly regrettable.
The story in itself is really interesting, they just didn't deliver well on the characters.
That's it, 4 in total. Skip this ifyou're not a die-hard Fate fan.

Fate/Apocrypha. A parallel universe to the well-known Fate/Stay Night series. During its aring time it caused a lot of debates, concerning the specific characters and the adaptation.
Since this is my first review, I'm gonna try to keep this brief. 
Story : 6/10
If I'd see a short script, structuring the plot of this series, I would be totally fascinated and say it's brilliant. However, when it comes to the execution I have some complaints. 
What makes this Fate different is the significant fact that there are actually 14 servants and masters participating in a grail war instead of 7. At first it's a 7 vs 7(Team Red vs Team Black). Once those teams finish their clash, the winners fight among themselves in order to determine one single winner, who shall recieve any wish. The first episode tries to explain this and many other aspects of the Holy Grail War within the first episode, which I didn't find very entertaining because it just throws a bunch information towards the viewer who might consequently lose interest immediately. However, the plot advances quickly after this episode. It introduces us to a lot of interesting and likable characters and overall has a really good start. Nevertheless, the flaws become quite visible later on (especially towards the end), which are mainly thanks to the annoying Main Character. I'll avoid to talk about those flaws for now due to spoiler reasons. Furthermore, the show has alot of action scenes due to its big character cast. So if you are looking for something with a great number of battle scenes, you should definetelly check this out.

Overall, the Story has a great structure and is basically really enjoyable to watch, but slighty starts to fail with the execution, in terms of writing, as it advances after the first cour.


Art and Animation : 9/10

This is definetelly one of the strongest elements of the series.

The Studio behind this is A-1 Pictures.

To start of with the Animation: The Animation is clearly one of the best and memorable I've seen. I guess that's to be expected from the Nasuverse. For some reason I've heard some complaints about the animation which I can't understand. I assume, it's because many confuse the artstyle wtih the animation. However, I think everyone can agree to the fact that episode 22 delivered a really splendid and smooth Sakuga-Animation. I would even go that far to call it the best animated episode of 2017. Nevertheless, I think the Animation could've still been done a little bit better, when it comes to certain scenes. I believe they can be fixed with the Blu Ray release. To be honest, I was really surprised how much effort A-1 put into the budget and would love to see more of something like that from A-1.

The Artstyle is something I enjoyed as well. Especially the characters looked really great (I'm looking at you, Jeanne). Nonetheless, similiar to the Animation, the Artstyle didn't stay consistent and had some changes, especially towards the end. A good example for that is once again episode 22 where they decided to give up the art quality in order to improve the Animation and go with Sakuga. I would be lying if I said that I liked the Artstyle within that episode but that's what Sakuga is about.

Overall, I am very satisfied with the Art and Animation


Sound : 8/10

I don't have much to say about the sound. At the beginning several fight scenes had very weird sound effects, which were quite horrible. They didn't really match up and were rather annoying. I gotta admit, it improved as the series advanced. 

The Soundtrack, which was composed by Masaru Yokoyama, was just great. Some of the tracks were a bit overused, but they totally matched up with the scenes and had a great impact on them. The Openings and Endings as well proved themselves to be one of my favourites.


Character : 7/10

This is the part where I have a lot to discuss about.

Due to the exceptional Grail War Rules this Fate consists a ton of characters. 24 (only counting the important ones) to be precise. And that's the problem. Since the series is only 25 episodes long, there is no way all of them could've recieved a proper developement. Though I gotta admit that I personally loved almost all of them, excluding the Main Character. They could've been waaay better, if they had more time to shine. Speaking of the MC, he's the element which dragged the seires down a lot and almost ruined it for me. He appeared to be a very uninteresting and generic character to me, who only destroys the series's potential.  I dare to say that if he didn't exist, this Fate could've had the potential to be as great as Fate/Zero. It's clear to assume that this Fate could've worked really well if it didn't have a MC in the first place or, on my behalf, focused more on Mordred and Kairi. I would've loved to see more of their amazing character interactions. Those two were probably the best executed characters of this series. Apart from that I highly enjoyed Shakespeare, Astolfo and "his" attitude, Ruler (though I unfortunetelly don't have much to say about her) and Shirou. Even though Shirou deserved a way better treatment as a character in the series. I loved many of the other characters as well, even though (as I mentioned before) some of them had too little screentime and developement. But it would be too much too present every single one of them now.


Enjoyment : 9/10

Enjoyment plays a major role to my rating when it comes to Anime. And I gotta say, even if this series had some significant flaws, it kept me being really excited to watch the next episode. That is due to elements I've already pointed out. Specific characters, for instance Shakespeare, kept me entertained and the Animation had influence on that part as well.

Overall, I can say that this series was a very enjoyable experience and had my full attention during the summer and fall season 2017.



Overall, we conclude to a final score of 8/10.

Warning: May contain spoilers. Proceed at your own risk.
The Fate series is an unwieldly beast of a franchise.  Spin offs galore.  Even the spinoffs have spinoffs.  The world of Fate contains a cinematic universe that Marvel and DC couldn’t compare in sheer size and convolution.  It all began with the visual novel Fate/Stay Night created by Type-Moon all the way back in 2004.  Fate/Stay Night follows protagonist Shiro Emiya as he participates unwittingly in the Holy Grail War.  The war always takes place in Fuyuki City.  As is common with many visual novels, there are three main routesbased on which girl you want to pursue.  The basic premise for the entire franchise has remained mostly the same since then.  Seven mages participate in a battle royale to obtain the Holy Grail, a literal plot device at supposedly grants the wishes of the winner.  Each mage must summon a familiar called a Servant.  Servants are historic and mythical figures that fight for their master.  Each Servant is designated a class.  These classes include Saber, Archer, Caster, Rider, Lancer, Assassin, and Berserker.  The master is given command seals that allow them to force a Heroic Spirit to obey a command regardless of will.  Masters are reluctant to use the seals as they will lose the war if all have been used.  A battle royale like this provides plenty opportunity for high stakes drama and intrigue.  Not to mention how awesome it is to see such figures of legend battling each other for supremacy.  Its like fantasy football for history/literature nerds like myself.  Fate/Stay Night was very successful (even though the West has yet to get an official release) and spawned many, and I mean many spinoffs.  Anime, games, light novels, manga, and many more related media that I can’t think of.  Along with all spinoffs and extended universes are sperate series that take place in the same universe (Tsukihime, Kara no Kyoukai).


Newcomers can be scared off by the sheer volume of Fate.  While Fate/Apocrypha doesn’t need prior knowledge of the series, its recommended you watch several other anime in the Fate series.  My foray into the Fate franchise began when I watched Studio Deen’s 2006 adaptation of Fate/Stay Night.  The series was inconsistent due to problems with the main character and the Deen’s ambition to try incorporating all three routes into one series.  While commendable, it made this version feel unfocused.  Shiro hurt the series due to his reckless behavior without any explanation.  He acts dumb most of the time.  This is where the meme “people die if they are killed” comes from.  Oh yeah, and shitty CG dragons as a metaphor for sex.  Deen/Stay Night has its moments, like when Archer sacrifices himself in one of the most badass moments in anime history and an awesome main antagonist.  The series is a good starting point and found myself intrigued by the rest of the franchise.  Try to begin here if you can.  You will appreciate the rest of the franchise much more.


Next, I watched Fate/Zero, a prequel to the events that unfolded in Fate/Stay Night.  Fate/Zero was produced by Ufotable.  It quickly became one of my favorite anime.  Gone is the high school setting and the cast is all adults with varying motivations and alignments presented maturely.  It blew Deen’s Fate out of the water in production values and writing.  Ufotable next put out Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Bladeworks, which had even more stunning visuals than Zero and even fixed many of the issues with Shiro.  That said, I was disappointed in it as a sequel to Fate/Zero.  Deen’s Fate had a more compelling villain and less anticlimactic moments.


Now we finally arrive to Fate/Apocrypha.  It has almost nothing to do with the main series, save for a few references.  Fate/Apocrypha takes place in an alternate timeline and no the war is no longer in Fuyuki.  Fate sees the franchise change studios yet again.  A-1 Pictures handled the production of Apocrypha.  I have a love/hate relationship with A-1.  They’ve made some great stuff (Birdy The Mighty:Decode, Seven Deadly Sins) and some not so good things (SAO, Aldnoah Zero).  One thing you can always count on with A-1 is excellent visuals and animation.  Everything else will be hit or miss.  Sitting in the director chair is Yoshiyuki Asai, whose only other directorial experience is Charlotte.  Charlotte was amazing for the first 8 ½ episodes until tanking in spectacular fashion.  I still shake my head about the last episode.  That aside, let’s get into the meat of this series.

Fate/Apocrypha shakes up the formula a little bit.  Instead of the usual 7-way battle royale, it’s a 7 on 7 tag team battle.  On one side is the Black Faction led by Darnic Prestone Yggdmillenia.  Why does anime have to give ridiculous names like these that are impossible to say or spell?  Yggdmillenia holds the Holy Grail in their hands aim to maintain supremacy.  The Red Faction represents the Mage’s Association with forces led by Shirou Kotomine, a representative of the Church.  


The story of Apocrypha starts out straight forward but quickly darts in different directions.  What seems like a simple two-sided war for the Grail soon see the two factions fracture.  Who can you trust?  There will be times when members of both sides must work together.  The plot unfolds mostly through battles between the Servants.  On the surface, Darnic seems like he leads the Black faction its his Servants who’s actually called the shots.  Lancer of Black, Vlad the Impaler, acts as the true leader of the Blacks.  He’s as commanding and arrogant as you’d expect.  The Black faction is conducting experiments with homunculi.  One of them escapes confinement and is saved in secret by Rider of Black.  The homunculus is later named Sieg and becomes close with his savior.    The mages of the Red faction are never shown on screen.  Only two masters on the Red are ever shown, Shirou and Kairi.  This immediately sets off red flags.  Kairi does not trust Shirou and prefers to act on his own.  


Fate/Apocrypha is less complex and convoluted compared to its cousins.  This is both a blessing and a curse.  It isn’t as dialogue driven as Zero but that results in less developed characters, even though I like most of the cast.  Apocrypha is more focused than the other Fate/ Stay Night adaptations.  It seems more shonen than most of the other titles in the series.  Apocrypha’s battle heavy plot means you won’t be getting bored.  The battles are unique in that the Servants display many different abilities that give impressive visual spectacles.  Each Servant posseses a Noble Phantasm.  Its like a character’s Final Smash in Super Smash Bros.  A Noble Phantasm is closely related to the myth or story surrounding a specific heroic spirit.  Noble Phantasms are very powerful and require considerable mana, meaning they are usually a last resort.  To get the most enjoyment out of this series, don’t take it too seriously.  Just enjoy the spectacle of it all.  It will provide plenty of entertainment.  Apocrypha is comparable to Hollywood blockbuster action films.  If you love intense action, Fate/Apocrypha is perfect for you. 


The sheer volume of characters is incredibly daunting.  Along with Black and Red Factions, is the special Servant Ruler, Jeanne d’Arc (yes that one).  She is summoned by the Grail to be an overseer of the Grail War.  Later, a homunculus named Sieg, who is saved by Rider of Black and looks to find a purpose for his short life.  Sieg and Jeanne will become central figures in the outcome of the war.  Sieg, Jeanne, and Astolfo (Rider of Black) become very close and work together to bring peace.  Another key relationship is between Kairi and Saber of Red.  Saber of Red’s true identity is Mordred, “son” of King Arthur.  Mordred resents her “father.”  That’s right, the son of King Arthur is female.  She is the offspring of Fate/Stay Night’s Saber, Arturia, who is also female.  Fate has some confusing/disturbing implications.  You don’t want to know how a woman can father a child.  It’s some hentai shit.  Kairi is a freelance mage contracted by the Mage’s Association to help win the Grail.  He is reluctant to join.  Kairi seems more like a mercenary than a mage, due to his roguish and rough nature.  Mordred couldn’t be more different from Arturia.  She is brutish and hot headed and wears very little clothing.  Kairi and Mordred hit it off almost immediately and begin a series long bromance.  Several of the Servants knew each other in their past life and makes for interesting character dynamics.  


The problem with a cast this huge is some characters don’t get enough screen time to develop.  Apocrypha did a surprisingly good job of fleshing out most of the characters.  Sieg’s journey to find purpose was quite compelling.  Jeanne’s desire to protect Seig and events of her life heavily impact the actions she takes.  Astofo is always there to support Sieg and is one of the best traps in anime.  Even less prominent characters like Fiore and Gordes Yggdmillenia and Rider of Red get some development.  Unfortunately, not all the characters faired well.  Darnic in particular was hardly developed.  Not good for someone who is being set up as the series antagonist.  Some of the Servants didn’t get enough attention like Lancer of Red and Caster of Black.  Their motivations didn’t resonate and had little explanation. 


Being an A-1 Pictures production, Fate/Apocrypha has stunning animation.  The battle scenes are orgasmic.  There were times the battle scenes that had my jaw on the floor.  This ranks as one of A-1’s better looking series.  Lots of sakuga to go around.  The animation was consistently great throughout its run with some episodes going above and beyond.  I’ve yet to see an A-1 series with legitimately terrible animation.  They do good work.  

The music was composed by Masaru Yokoyama, who is best known for composing the music for Your Lie In April, which has absolutely beautiful music.  Fate/Apocrypha also has great music.  Epic sounds to go along with the epic battles.  I watched the English dub it was solid for the most part.  Not many well known names in this dub but isn’t a problem.  Its good to see new voice talent rising in the industry.


Fate/Apocrypha is a fun, albeit shallow action romp.  Not much knowledge of the Fate franchise is need but still recommended.  You’ll get a better appreciation for the small references and understand the concepts shown here.  Apocrypha is more straight forward than its Fate brethren and even more action focused.  The animation and sound design is fantastic.  Add this to your watch list.

First of all:
If you didn't watch Fate/Stay Night (UBW) and/or Fate/Zero you should watch them first because some stuff like the command spells get explained in those series....
If you are one of those people that can't take it if someone hypes a show and then while you are watching you search for everything that the show does bad, you should just watch Fate/Apocrypha instead of reading my review ;)
contains some light spoilers regarding the servants

What is bad about this show ?:
- some servants didn't fit their role at all like the assassin of red, who was the whole time more a caster than an assassin...
-at the beginning I didn't like the OP's and ED's but after hearing them several times I really enjoyed them :)


- there were some minor logic errors like Sieg used one more command spell than he had ? (not sure....)


What is good about this show ?:


- I really love the new servants, everyone of them is unique with their own personality and there is even a trap XD (Astolfo is a guy dressed as a girl), berserker is a female "Frankenstein" that began suicide because she wanted someone to love or Caster who is Shakespeare and to be honest he was the whole show talking **** and that's it....


- The story itself is very original, it's still a death match about the holy grail that grants one wish but this time with a lot more servants and masters (24 n total, separated into 2 teams). Fate/Apocrypha had a lot of surprises in terns of story like it was very rare that one servant just dies (I can't say it sadly because I don't want to spoil anything :d).


- GOOSE BUMPS !!!! No really, I enjoyed the action scenes a lot.


Conclusion:


If you are ready for another round of the Fate franchise go watch it, it's on Netflix with DUB and SUB there is nothing to lose and in my opinion it's a bit more enjoyable than the other Fate series (take it with some salt over a year has passed since I watched FSN UBW....)


Some notes:


- my first review and I hate writing

- I don't speak English naively

- the Netflix subber fell for a trap and thought that Astolfo is a girl XD (in the German sub at least....)



Have a nice day :3

Fair warning, my only experience with Fate/Apocrypha is with this adaption.
Fate/Apocrypha's biggest problem is that it's too much. There's too many characters, too many plots, too many stories trying to be told in 25 episodes.
The story itself is cluttered with mini-arcs, less so in the first season, but it gets a bit much in the second season. It's a good story and quite interesting, particularly if you're familiar with Fate/Stay Night and Fate/Zero, but it gets bogged down by mini-plots that are hastily concluded so we can move on to the next one.
The art quality is pretty uneven. At times it is absolutely gorgeous, butthen the next scene can look like complete garbage.


I'm not an expert on sound quality, but there didn't seem to be anything wrong with it, but nothing outstanding either. 


 It doesn't help that the main character Sieg is about as exciting as watching paint dry. While he's certainly sympathetic in his efforts to save his fellow homunculi and to protect Ruler, he's just so boring. For all the shit that Emiya Shirou of Fate/Stay Night may get for his stupidity in parts of the VN and it's various adaptations, he's not boring. Sieg MIGHT have become less boring if he'd had time to develop, but considering Apocrypha has literally dozens of characters all vying for screen time, he doesn't get it. The other characters are more colorful, but most don't get the screen time they deserve. Astolfo on the other hand gets entirely too much screen time and other than being extremely feminine, he has no real character traits that make him stand out or make him interesting. Ruler/Jeanne was a very interesting character up until SPOILERS!!!!

,

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.


She falls in love with Sieg. She still had some great development, but her story kept getting deflected to her love of Sieg, who is a cardboard cutout of a character. Mordred and her Master seemed like they were going to be the main characters early on in the show, but nope, we got fucking Sieg instead. I really liked the dynamic of their partnership and they seemed to be the best developed characters in the story overall. The Yggdmillennia faction Masters had some occasionally good moments, but for the most part, they were extremely bland characters. The same could be said for most of their Servants. I can't really go into the other characters without spoiling things, so we'll leave it there. 


It's an enjoyable series, but a bit frustrating at times.


I'll give a 6/10.

In a sentence: poor story and MCs, good side characters, awesome fight scenes.
If you are a new comer to the Fate universe, this is not the gateway for you. I believe that Fate/Apocrypha was made under the presumption that the viewer has already watched Fate/Zero, Fate/Stay Night(unlimited blade works included), as the exposition is very thin and if unversed in the Fate series lore, this show may well seem more a mess that it actually is. (This review is also written under the presumption that the reader is already initiated in Fate lore.)
However, if viewed just for the awesome fight scenes, this anime definitely answerswith its battles galore, barely a peaceful episode in between.


Story:3

There really isn't much of a story here. People fight for the Holy Grail, the participants want their wishes granted. Plot points from Fate/Zero and Unlimited Blade Works are shamelessly copied. Most notably the part were a servant goes crazy and threatens the peace of the world and everyone teams up to stop the evildoer(this actually happens twice), and the stupid Holy Grail arbitrarily awarding bodies to random servants. It might have seemed fresh when these plot points appeared in previous entries, but now it's just rehashing.


Those illusions that are supposed to break a person's spirit, they're just weak. I was not moved at all by those scenes, and I can't accept that those watered down talks can move anyone or sink anyone into despair, whatever their sob backstory. 


And the stupid death teases. So many death teases! How is it that servants, whose core is supposedly at their heart, can survive a through stab to the heart? And how can servants who have been stabbed through the heart unleash a noble phantasm? And how can servants who have been stabbed through the heart somehow stay alive through, I don't know, somehow existing on some random person running around? Some servants die simply because of a bunch of words, others die because they have been stabbed though the heart, others just...don't die?


Art:10

There really isn't anything to say about the art. Though not as polished or fluid as the 3D animation done by ufotable, A-1 pictures fully utilizes the tools of 2-D animation, offering a fantastic journey of countless imaginative, exciting, blood-pumping, fight scenes. The anime's worth it for the battle scenes alone. And episode 22. If nothing, just watch episode 22. The fight scenes will blow your mind about what hand-drawn animation is capable of.


Sound:7

It's standard fare for Fate, so I'll not dwell too much on it. Both Egoist and LiSA's ops are highly enjoyable.


Character:3

If only the anime dwelt on any character that wasn't Sieg or ruler. If only this anime focused on the ideals and selfishness of human nature and themes of saving the world, and not bring a close to all these philosophical discussions with... with what the anime ended up focusing on. There were interesting dynamics between many pairs of characters, and intriguing back stories. Just not Sieg and ruler. The young girl who became the chosen one and is actually lonely and the responsibility is just a curse that disables her from living a normal life, this was all done with sabre from fate/zero and stay night. No need to replay all of it again with ruler.


Sieg is the standard shounen hero who somehow gets op and defeats everyone despite not having actually worked hard for anything at all. He gets all his powers by default, because he is the MC. Oh dear.


Enjoyment:6

All my enjoyment came from the outstanding side characters, especially Mordred and her relationship with everyone else, most notably her master, and the awesome fight scenes. Enough can't be said about the superb fight scenes.


Overall:6

Well, if only we could have had more of any two people but ruler and Sieg. And anything but that cheesy story between them. If only for the fight scene, this would have gotten at least an eight. But ruler and Sieg... they are intolerable.


Unless you are not new to the fate universe, just jump to the fight scenes. The fight scenes are worth it. Really.

As a fan of the Fate series since the VN I was super disappointed in this show. As I started it I was like "Woah cool! A 7 vs 7 servant fight!" but as it dragged on it just got super muddled and boring. None of the characters motivations seem meaningful, and they all seem so shallow. Most of the the interesting characters get overlooked and less screen time for a certain boring couple. They literally spend 5-7 minutes per episode talking about what it mean to be human/freedom/ruler+homoculus ship. Overall the story is rushed and never makes since, the characters are boring and shallow,and the animation isn't even close to UBW. Super disappointing.

As someone who watched and enjoyed Fate/Zero and (to a lesser extent) Fate/Stay Night, when I heard an announcement for Fate/Apocrypha, I got extremely excited. I am personally not in touch with the various properties of Type-Moon and my only experience pretty much only extends to the anime and some of the manga so this would be a great opportunity to get into another one of their narratives. So this review is not in accordance to a fan that is aware of all the characters and such. Just someone who watched the anime and read some of the manga. However, upon looking up more details,I found some… interesting changes.


First of all, it was made by A1 pictures instead of Ufotable which raised my eyebrows. I got plenty of Sword Art Online vibes and I got pretty worried. But either way I still went ahead and watched it. Just to see how many comparisons or criticisms I could make.


I’m going to express my opinions on the ascetic details first because the plot and characters will be a doozy to talk about.


Animation and Visuals

Pretty good. I don’t think it’s on the same level as Fate/Zero and Stay Night. Some hiccups here and there.

The fight scenes were well choreographed sometimes and other times they were hard to follow. So in other words, they were amazing.

However, some faces look REALLY punchable. Mainly Shiro’s stupid grinning face makes him look like a punching bag. I feel that his stupid grinning face is what caused a lot of my probably undeserved hatred for him.

Music

I have no complaints about the music. Apart from the fact that it is simply not as good as Zero and Stay Night. So placing the music any lower would be a tad unfair.


Plot

Fate/Apocrypha takes place during the Great Grail War, where multiple “masters” summon an individual “servant” to assist in winning the Holy Grail.

The Great Grail War utilises not the usual seven, but a whopping fourteen masters where it is a seven on seven team battle with two factions, Red and Black (they had better names, just using simpler ones because the plot is very complicated for newcomers). 

Each master summons an individual “servant” to aid them in the war. Each servant is basically a super-powered person who also happens to be a famous figure in history (Mordred, Dracula and Frankenstein’s monster get summoned, just to name a few). To regulate the war, a special servant is summoned (Jean of Arc).


So right off the bat, since fourteen masters summon fourteen servants, we run into a problem right away – There are 14 + 14 + 1 = 29 main characters that are all thrown at the audience at once. Now I’m no master storyteller, but it was clear that a chunk of the main characters had to be shafted simply to fit into a 25 episode run. Some characters don’t even have speaking roles which is fine I guess. I mean, there’s no way they could manage so many characters without an official introduction. Which is a shame, because one of the main strengths of Fate/Zero and Stay Night is the dichotomy between servant and master. You’re seeing a pattern right? 


But the second half starts, and this is where the plot becomes overcomplicated. It throws the original plot out the window and becomes your stereotypical “Save the World” plot. What a drag. If you started at that point, then you wouldn’t need the first 11 episodes. It holds very little attachment to its premise so even explaining the whole Great Grail War feels like a waste. Throw in a few continuity errors from other parts and you have a convoluted plot that forgets itself faster than it forgets its characters.

I feel like the series would have performed better if it was split into two 25 episode parts, as then it would have had more time to develop each character and maybe the plot would have more time to not be as complicated.


Characters

So much wasted potential. Like I said earlier, they shaft a huge chunk of the cast at the beginning which they only did because there really was no room. With so much of the cast shafted, another character is added. Naturally, he gets more development than any other character despite having no involvement in the war. His relationship with Jean is also very hackneyed and borderline ahistorical. The plot pushed their relationship so hard that they even have their swords cross together like in all the Sword Art Online openings.

Let’s start with the masters. As a staple of the Fate series, masters are only as interesting as how their relationship with their servant is. However, most of the masters that have any sense of connection with their servant are the young ones, which is disappointing, as it leaves many of the servants underdeveloped as they have no one to have their conflicting personalities to play off of.

Shiro and his stupid punching bag face, is a special exception. His relationship to his servant is probably developed off-screen but they are not given enough screen time to show such development. And we don’t even learn what her relationship to him is in relation to her identity. I had to look her up and find out some interesting stuff. But the problem is that I should not have to look up a character to understand their actions and even then it still does not explain her interactions with Shiro or other characters. Maybe it was explained in the novels or something but it results in both characters being underdeveloped despite applying such integral roles.


But we all know why we’re here right? The servants. Just looking at an interpretation of a famous historical figure is what we’re all here to fawn over.


I feel one of the main problems is that the servants are exclusively introduced by their name rather than their actions since from the very beginning, every single servant is given massive expectations simply from their names. Also, since all fourteen servants are introduced immediately, there’s no mystery. We don’t ask questions like “Who’s that guy?” or “Who would have a weapon like that?” and instead we ask “What was the point of that guy?” which is the worst question to ask when introducing new characters. I mean, what was the point of Red Caster? Of Red Berserker? Even servants that have development are not interesting in the slightest because there is nothing in there character arc that links to their identity. I will make some important statements that link to just how obsolete some characters are:

If Red Caster was not in the story, the story would not change. He serves no purpose and if he was killed by accident in episode 1, then the story would carry out the same way.

If Black Rider’s identity was someone else, then his actions will be the exact same. We learn who he is, but his identity does not impact any area of the story. He is just there to be the trap character. Despite doing a lot of things in the story, there is no link between his actions and his identity. If he was a horse, then at least his identity would serve a purpose.

With 14 characters expected to have more screen time with half the episodes of Zero and Stay Night, some of them naturally get shafted. Dracula in particular, I expected to get more screen time since the setting was Romania but for most of the series, he just sits around and plays chess. And since he’s introduced immediately as Dracula, you expect him to act more like Dracula, as he’s a combination between the novel by Bram Stoker and the historical figure Vlad III. He should be more blood thirsty, dine in front of corpses like in the historical pictures or something. Maybe Vlad could have been hidden for a bit. Maybe he could have a constant presence throughout the story. Just have a bit of mystery. All 14 (Plus Jean) servants only give us expectation but no mystery. It removes all sense of surprise to the audience which is just disappointing. The only surprise you receive is that the characters don’t live up to expectation.


Overall

The series is just a waste of potential. If I have to look for a reason to care about basically every character, then that’s no good. If you want a better series to get into, watch Fate/Zero or Fate/Stay Night Unlimited Blade Works.

Yay, yet another Fate spin-off that won't bring anything to the lore or the story! And it's not Ufotable on top of that! What could go wrong? Except everything, of course.
STORY
Apocrypha is YET ANOTHER alternate version of the Fate universe. While the new version of the Holy Grail War is interesting (it involves a war between 2 factions instead of 7 individual mage families), not only this spin-off is pointless (as it's a new "timeline"), the anime also didn't manage to develop anything properly. Most of the characters are poorly written, most of the story is full of absurdities, and ALL of it is uselessto the franchise. It is the very definition of a cash grab.


It involves some known characters, but they are definitely not the same as their original counterparts.


As a result, this spin-off doesn't expand the original universe at all. Rather it takes what made its success, blended it in a sort of random mix, and delivered a product that they KNOW will sell well because it is the Fate franchise...



ART

This is A1-Pictures. While their job on SAO is far from bad, the rest isn't very appealing...

But even then, Apocrypha was still a huge disappointment. Most of it is still pictures, the fights are mainly made of dialogues (God I hate it when mortal enemies talk to each other like they're good friends or colleagues...), and worst of all, the battles are ugly af! In some fights (especially the final ones), everything is distorted, the characters look like shit, the explosions look like shit, everything looks just... bad.

Not only that, the colors are too pale.



SOUND

The music is nice. The SINGLE music, I mean. Because the OST feels like it's made of only one track, which itself is repetitive af. This is the very definition of "music poverty": just make a few notes, make a loop out of it, and hope that the consumer is dumb enough to not notice that.

As for the opening, I never liked Egoist's singer, so I hate the first opening. But LiSA's opening is a bit better to hear, although it's the usual stuff.



CHARACTER

This is one of those cases where the characters are so badass most people don't even realize how blend they are.

I'll be blunt: most characters are flat as hell. They have almost no development whatsoever.

Red Saber and her Master, for example: they look awesome, they are awesome, BUT they disappear for almost half of the show and haven't changed one bit in the end.

Although, to be honest, this issue mainly comes from the lack of time. Apocrypha has a LOT of characters, and only 25 episodes. This is what ruins most of the characters.


That, and the fact that most of them are stupid as f*ck.

Jeanne d'Arc is a perfect example of that. Remember this battle in the middle of the anime, when she keeps running in the middle and changing directions? "I have to go that way! Oh, no, it was the other direction! Oh no I was wrong, it's over there!" Jeez.

Or that time in the first episodes when a faction attacks Jeanne: they fight for a minute, then Jeanne says "I am not your enemy", the others say "ok" and they just leave. Like, just like that?


But the worst of all is the "hero", Sieg. If I were asked who is the worst anime character ever, that dude takes the cake. He is the LEAST INTERESTING character ever. Not only is he useless most of the time, he's from those characters who have a power-up taken off their ass, he is blend as f*ck... and they tried to put him in a r*cking romantic relationship with Jeanne?


Jeez, that has to be the worst romance ever.



ENJOYMENT

I love the Fate series. But only the main ones (that includes Fate/Stay Night and Fate/Zero).

The rest of it is just a bunch of shameless cash grab.
